messageBody:
Using the Arabic script to represent English

Adapting Arabic to represent spoken English would be similar to
adapting Latin. Spoken English has 14 pure vowels, early Latin had
10 but only represented five. The Arabic writing system marks five
vowels. Therefore, one of the first steps would be to add 9 shapes
or diacritics to Arabic to handle the additional vowels.

The Arabic writing system has other peculiarities such as medial and
terminal forms. Arabic vowels have tone and length which can be
marked in the writing system. English vowels have neither although
we still talk about length.

The Arabic writing system (ajami) has one advantage over the
standard Roman orthography. Standard Arabic, like Hausa,
distinguishes long and short vowels. Thus, when Hausa speakers write
Hausa using ajami, they show vowel length as is normally done in
Arabic, i.e. with the normal vowel points and alif showing long a,
waw showing long u, and ya showing long i.

Arabic does not have the vowels e and o. When Hausa speakers write
Hausa using ajami, they use the same symbols to write both o and u
(both long and short). One must therefore know the words to know
which vowel, o or u, is intended. Ajami does have a way to
distinguish e from other vowels. A large point or dot under a
consonant shows vocalization with a short e, and that dot,
supplemented with a vertical stroke above the consonant shows
vocalization with a long e.

If anyone knows of an adapted Arabic script for Enlish, I would be
interested in looking at it.

The Turks thought so highly of the Arabic writing system that they
switched to an extended Latin alphabet.

Regards,

Steve
